awd_abstract_narration:
With the advent of large scale distributed storage systems, cloud computing and commercial data storage applications, there is a renewed interest in the coding and information theory in reliabile issues data storage. In large networked databases, faster updates and quick repair requirements must be integrated with reliable data storage protocols. These requirements bring new dimensions and parameters to the traditional optimization problem of information theory.

In this project we propose, for the first time, a model of large-scale storage that accounts for the topology of storage networks. Previously, storage topology was never a concern of the code designers. Further, we study the update efficiency and local repair (fast recovery) properties of error-correcting codes suitable for storage. For all of these, we will analyze the fundamental limits of systems, as well as propose explicit (fast algorithmic) constructions of codes. Several tools from graph and network theory, combinatorics and optimization theory will be leveraged to find performance limits and devise coding algorithms.

By cutting redundancy and allowing faster processing, the codes developed from this project will directly save energy consumption in data centers. Existing and new collaborations of the principal investigator will facilitate industry cooperation and increase the transition to practice of results generated from this project. Elements of this endeavor will be integrated with the courses taught by the principal investigator. The findings will be disseminated through publications in peer-reviewed venues and made available in the form of technical reports for public access on the investigator's webpage. Finally, motivated by practical applications and extending across various disciplines, this project is representative of an intriguing area of engineering science, and will attract a diverse student base including undergraduate students.

por.por_cntn:
This project was devoted towards developing coding and information theoretic methods for distributed large scale storage and computation. In particular, this project addressed the issues of reliability in distributed networked storage systems, and developed error correcting codes that are tailored for such systems. As a by-product, this project found fundamental information theoretic limits of reliable information storage in large scale systems, and developed tools that are applicable to distributed computing, as well as machine learning methods. 
Throughout this project, several foundational scientific results were obtained: 1) this project developed a full theory of locally repairable codes, error-correcting codes suitable for distributed storage, by deriving their optimal parameters, constructions, and information-theoretic treatments; 2) this project introduced the notion of storage codes on networks that enable efficient repair, and provided both constructions and limits of such codes; 3) this project derived methods for communication-efficient optimization over large networks, that are also delay-tolerant; and finally 4) this project developed statistical models for heterogeneous data spread over large distributed networks. One graduate student was supported fully by this grant for their entire PhD, whereas two other graduate students and one postdoc were supported in part by this grant over the past seven years. The elements of this project have been incorporated into newly designed/redesigned courses of information theory, coding theory, optimization, and data science at University of Massachusetts Amherst and at University of  California, San Diego.
Several invited and contributed talks on the results of this project have been delivered by the PI, graduate students and postdocs in universities, industrial research labs and in conferences. The project also led to collaborations with other faculty members and postdoctoral researchers. The collaborative nature also led to organization of special sessions on dedicated topics within international conferences, as well as organizations of at least two focused special-topic workshops. The results of this project have been disseminated via at least ten (10) journal papers and twenty-four (24) highly selective conference papers.
